Tomato___Late_blight.description: A serious fungal disease caused by Phytophthora infestans that affects tomatoes and potatoes. It spreads rapidly in cool, wet conditions and can destroy entire crops within days.
Tomato___Late_blight.remedy: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. Apply copper-based fungicides preventively. Improve air circulation by spacing plants properly. Avoid overhead irrigation. Use resistant varieties when possible.

Tomato___Early_blight.description: A fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani that affects tomato leaves, stems, and fruits. It typically appears as dark brown spots with concentric rings.
Tomato___Early_blight.remedy: Remove infected leaves and destroy them. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper. Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash. Water at the base of plants. Rotate crops annually.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: A fungal disease caused by Passalora fulva that thrives in high humidity and poor air circulation. It appears as yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces with olive-green spores underneath.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.remedy: Improve air circulation by spacing plants properly. Reduce humidity by watering early in the day. Apply fungicides if necessary. Remove and destroy infected leaves. Use resistant varieties.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: A fungal disease caused by Septoria lycopersici that creates small, circular spots with dark borders and gray centers on tomato leaves.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.remedy: Remove infected leaves immediately. Apply fungicides containing copper or chlorothalonil. Mulch to prevent soil splash. Water at the base of plants. Rotate crops and clean up debris.

Tomato___Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider.description: Tiny arachnids that feed on plant sap, causing stippling, yellowing, and webbing on tomato leaves. They thrive in hot, dry conditions.
Tomato___Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider.remedy: Spray plants with strong water to dislodge mites. Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil. Introduce predatory mites. Maintain adequate humidity. Remove heavily infested leaves.

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: A fungal disease caused by Corynespora cassiicola that creates target-like lesions with concentric rings on tomato leaves and stems.
Tomato___Target_Spot.remedy: Remove infected plant parts. Apply fungicides containing azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil. Improve air circulation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Use resistant varieties when available.

Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: A viral disease transmitted by whiteflies that causes yellowing, curling, and stunting of tomato leaves. It can significantly reduce yields.
Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.remedy: Control whiteflies with insecticides or sticky traps. Remove infected plants immediately. Use resistant varieties. Plant early to avoid peak whitefly season. Use reflective mulches.

Tomato___mosaic_virus.description: A viral disease that causes mottled, distorted leaves and reduced fruit quality. It can be transmitted by insects, tools, or human contact.
Tomato___mosaic_virus.remedy: Remove and destroy infected plants. Control aphids and other insect vectors. Disinfect tools between plants. Wash hands after handling infected plants. Use resistant varieties.

Tomato___healthy.description: Healthy tomato plant with no visible signs of disease or pest damage.
Tomato___healthy.remedy: Continue current care practices. Maintain regular watering, fertilization, and monitoring for early signs of problems.

Potato___Early_blight.description: A fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani that affects potato leaves, creating dark brown spots with concentric rings. It can reduce yields and tuber quality.
Potato___Early_blight.remedy: Remove infected leaves. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper. Mulch to prevent soil splash. Water at the base of plants. Rotate crops and clean up debris.

Potato___Late_blight.description: A devastating fungal disease caused by Phytophthora infestans that can destroy entire potato crops rapidly in cool, wet conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.remedy: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately. Apply copper-based fungicides preventively. Improve drainage and air circulation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Use resistant varieties.

Potato___healthy.description: Healthy potato plant with no visible signs of disease or pest damage.

Pepper_bell___Bacterial_spot.description: A bacterial disease caused by Xanthomonas campestris that creates small, water-soaked spots on pepper leaves and fruits. It can spread rapidly in wet conditions.
Pepper_bell___Bacterial_spot.remedy: Remove infected plant parts. Avoid overhead irrigation. Apply copper-based bactericides. Improve air circulation. Use disease-free seeds. Rotate crops annually.

Pepper_bell___healthy.description: Healthy bell pepper plant with no visible signs of disease or pest damage.

Peach___Bacterial_spot.remedy: Apply copper-based bactericides during dormancy and early spring. Prune to improve air circulation. Remove and destroy infected plant parts. Use resistant varieties when available.

Peach___healthy.description: Healthy peach tree with no visible signs of disease or pest damage.

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.remedy: Remove infected leaves and debris. Apply fungicides containing captan or thiram. Improve air circulation. Avoid overhead irrigation. Use resistant varieties and clean planting material.

Strawberry___healthy.description: Healthy strawberry plant with no visible signs of disease or pest damage.

Apple___Apple_scab.description: A fungal disease caused by Venturia inaequalis that creates dark, scabby lesions on apple leaves and fruits. It can cause significant yield losses and fruit quality issues.
Apple___Apple_scab.remedy: Apply fungicides during early spring. Prune to improve air circulation. Remove and destroy fallen leaves and fruit. Use resistant varieties. Apply dormant oil sprays.

Apple___Black_rot.description: A fungal disease caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa that affects apple fruits, leaves, and branches. It can cause fruit rot and canker formation on branches.
Apple___Black_rot.remedy: Prune and destroy infected branches. Remove mummified fruits. Apply fungicides during bloom and early fruit development. Improve air circulation through proper pruning.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: A fungal disease that requires both apple trees and cedar trees to complete its life cycle. It creates orange spots on apple leaves and fruits.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.remedy: Remove cedar trees within 2 miles if possible. Apply fungicides during early spring. Use resistant apple varieties. Prune to improve air circulation. Remove infected plant parts.

Apple___healthy.description: Healthy apple tree with no visible signs of disease or pest damage.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: A fungal disease caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis that creates rectangular, gray-brown lesions on corn leaves. It can reduce yields in severe cases.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.remedy: Use resistant hybrids. Apply fungicides if necessary. Rotate crops. Remove and destroy crop debris. Ensure proper plant spacing for air circulation.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.description: A fungal disease caused by Puccinia sorghi that creates reddish-brown pustules on corn leaves. It typically doesn't cause significant yield loss in most cases.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.remedy: Use resistant hybrids. Apply fungicides only if disease pressure is high. Remove volunteer corn plants. Rotate crops. Monitor for early detection.
